 8 B.       The District Court Did Not Err in Denying Defendant’s Motion to Dismiss
 9          on Speedy Trial Grounds

10   {41}   The Speedy Trial Clause of the Sixth Amendment of the United States

11 Constitution provides that “[i]n all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the

12 right to a speedy . . . trial[.]” U.S. Const. amend. VI. “The heart of the right to a

13 speedy trial is preventing prejudice to the accused.” State v. Garza, 2009-NMSC-038,

14 ¶ 12,
146 N.M. 499
,
212 P.3d 387
. The right to a speedy trial “is unique among the

15 constitutional guarantees afforded a criminal defendant because of the concomitant

16 ‘societal interest in bringing an accused to trial.’ ” State v. Serros, 2016-NMSC-008,

17 ¶ 4,
366 P.3d 1121
 (quoting Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶ 12). “As a result, merely

18 showing delay in bringing an accused’s case to trial is not enough to establish a

19 speedy trial violation; rather, [the appellate courts] must scrutinize every claimed

20 violation to determine whether the accused has suffered an actual and articulable

                                             19
  1 deprivation of the right to a speedy trial.” Serros, 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 4 (internal

 2 quotation marks and citation omitted).

 3   {42}   We evaluate Defendant’s claim that his Sixth Amendment right to a speedy

 4 trial was violated using the four factors set out in Barker v. Wingo,
407 U.S. 514
, 530

 5 (1972): “(1) the length of the delay in bringing the case to trial, (2) the reasons for the

 6 delay, (3) the defendant’s assertion of the right to a speedy trial; and (4) the prejudice

 7 to the defendant caused by the delay.” Id.; see also Serros, 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 5.

 8 1.       Length of Delay

 9   {43}   “The first factor, the length of delay, has a dual function: it acts as a triggering

10 mechanism for considering the four Barker factors if the delay crosses the threshold

11 of being presumptively prejudicial, and it is an independent factor to consider in

12 evaluating whether a speedy trial violation has occurred.” Serros, 2016-NMSC-

13 008,¶ 22. As to the first function, our Supreme Court “[has] established benchmarks

14 for presumptively prejudicial delay according to the complexity of a case: one year

15 for a simple case, 15 months for a case of intermediate complexity, and 18 months for

16 a complex case.” Id. ¶ 22 (citing Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶ 48). In this case, the

17 State concedes (and we agree) that the twenty-nine month, twenty-two day-long delay

18 between Defendant’s arrest and his trial is sufficient to trigger further analysis for a

19 speedy trial violation regardless of the complexity of the case.


                                                 20
  1   {44}   As to the second, “independent” function that the first Barker factor performs,

 2 our Supreme Court has stated that “[t]he length of delay is an objective determination

 3 that is capable of measurement with some precision, and once established, it colors

 4 the rest of the speedy trial analysis. A delay that crosses the threshold for presumptive

 5 prejudice necessarily weighs in favor of the accused; the only question is, how

 6 heavily?” Serros, 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 26. Importantly, “the parties’ fault in causing

 7 the delay is irrelevant to the analysis” of this factor. Id. “A delay that scarcely crosses

 8 the bare minimum needed to trigger judicial examination of the claim is of little help

 9 to a defendant claiming a speedy trial violation.” Id. (internal quotation marks and

10 citation omitted). “Conversely, an extraordinary delay . . . weighs heavily in favor of

11 a defendant’s speedy trial claim, bearing in mind that no single factor is dispositive

12 of whether a violation has occurred.” Id.; See Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶ 24.

13   {45}   As an initial matter, we note that our Supreme Court in Serros did not explain

14 how to determine the difference between a presumptively prejudicial delay that

15 “scarcely crosses the bare minimum needed” and provides “little help to a defendant”

16 versus the additional length of delay that would be considered “extraordinary” and

17 that “weighs heavily in favor of a defendant’s speedy trial claim.” Id. (internal

18 quotation marks and citation omitted). In Serros, our Supreme Court concluded that

19 weighing the first factor heavily in the defendant’s favor was not a “difficult


                                               21
  1 question” because the fifty-one month long delay between the defendant’s arrest and

 2 the dismissal of his indictment for speedy trial violations was far in excess of the

 3 amount needed to create a presumption of prejudice. Id. ¶ 24.

 4   {46}   Here, the nearly twenty-nine month delay between Defendant’s arrest and his

 5 trial is more than the “bare minimum needed” to show presumptive prejudice, but

 6 significantly shorter than the fifty-one month delay that Serros concluded weighed

 7 heavily in the defendant’s favor as a matter of course. Id. ¶ 26 (internal quotation

 8 marks and citation omitted). Moreover, the district court in this case did not make an

 9 express finding as to the complexity of Defendant’s case. The complexity of this case

10 does not matter to our determination of presumptive prejudice because the amount of

11 delay is sufficient to trigger a speedy trial analysis regardless of the case’s

12 complexity. See id. ¶ 23 (concluding the delay presumptively prejudicial without

13 determining the case’s complexity). But with respect to how we are to evaluate this

14 length of delay factor, the complexity of this case takes on considerable importance.

15 If the case is classified as simple, then the delay exceeds the threshold for

16 presumptive prejudice by seventeen months; if intermediate, fourteen; if complex,

17 only eleven. See id. ¶ 22 (recognizing that the amount of time that must elapse for

18 delay to become presumptively prejudicial is “one year for a simple case, 15 months




                                             22
  1 for a case of intermediate complexity, and 18 months for a complex case” (citing

 2 Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶ 48)).

 3   {47}   The State argues that this is a case of “intermediate” complexity based on “the

 4 number of potential witnesses and scenarios that were involved.” Specifically, the

 5 State asserts that it was required to prepare for a trial involving testimony of the

 6 checks’ owners, the employees of the businesses where Defendant allegedly passed

 7 the checks off, records custodians who could lay the foundation for the admission of

 8 surveillance camera footage, and any law enforcement personnel involved in the

 9 investigations that led to Defendant’s arrest. We agree that the State’s assessment of

10 this case’s complexity is reasonable, and accordingly, find that the length of the delay

11 in this case was fourteen months in excess of the amount necessary to trigger judicial

12 scrutiny.

13   {48}   In Serros, our Supreme Court concluded that a fifty-one month delay between

14 the defendant’s arrest and the dismissal of the indictment against him on speedy trial

15 grounds was “extreme” and therefore justified weighing the first Barker factor

16 heavily in the defendant’s favor. Serros, 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 24. By contrast, in

17 Garza, our Supreme Court determined that a delay that only exceeded the amount

18 required to trigger further judicial analysis by a month and six days “was not

19 extraordinary and [did] not weigh heavily in [the d]efendant’s favor.” Garza, 2009-


                                              23
  1 NMSC-038, ¶ 24. Here, the delay in this case exceeds the amount required to trigger

 2 further analysis by fourteen months. This delay is far more than the “bare minimum

 3 needed to trigger judicial examination of the claim.” Id. (internal quotation marks and

 4 citation omitted). Accordingly, we conclude that this factor weighs heavily in

 5 Defendant’s favor.

 6 2.       The Reasons Behind the Delay

 7   {49}   The district court found that most of the delay in this case was attributable to

 8 Defendant. As we have stated above, we give deference to the district court’s finding

 9 of fact that Defendant caused most of the delay in this case, to the extent it is

10 supported by substantial evidence in the record. See Serros, 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 20.

11   {50}   Defendant argues that the State is responsible for twenty-four out of the

12 twenty-nine months of delay in this case. Defendant asserts that the delay between

13 February 2011 and February 2012 was caused by the State’s filing of a motion to join

14 Defendant’s case with that of his alleged co-conspirators’ and the district court’s

15 negligent failure to timely rule on the motion. Defendant argues that the State is

16 responsible for another two months of delay caused by its mistaken belief that

17 Defendant had absconded from custody when he was in fact in prison, thus causing

18 the district court to issue a bench warrant and continue the October 2012 trial setting

19 to December 2012. Finally, Defendant argues that he should not be held responsible


                                               24
  1 for the delays between April 2012 and April 2013, which Defendant argues was

 2 caused by motions to continue filed by his trial counsel which he did not consent to

 3 filing. We assess and assign responsibility for the delays in this case chronologically.

 4   {51}   We agree with Defendant that the delay caused by the State’s motion to join

 5 (and the district court’s failure to rule on the motion) is properly weighed in

 6 Defendant’s favor. Accordingly, twelve of the twenty-nine month period of delay in

 7 this case weighs in Defendant’s favor. In doing so, we reject the State’s argument that

 8 the delay should not be weighed against it because the motion had merit and was

 9 ultimately granted as unopposed in modified form. Whatever the merit of the motion,

10 the State’s decision to file it occasioned the district court’s delay until it ruled on the

11 motion. Accordingly, this period of time is appropriately weighed more heavily

12 against the State. See Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶¶ 26-30 (noting that delays caused

13 by administrative burdens on the court system are typically weighed slightly in the

14 defendant’s favor, but the more “protracted” the delay, the more heavily it is weighed

15 in the defendant’s favor).

16   {52}   We disagree with Defendant’s assertion that the period of delay from April

17 2012 to April 2013 is the fault of the State. Defendant argues that he asserted his right

18 to a speedy trial by filing a pro se motion to dismiss his attorney in which he also

19 demanded to proceed to trial. We are mindful that the right to a speedy trial and the


                                               25
  1 right to effective assistance of counsel are not mutually exclusive. Serros, 2016-

 2 NMSC-008, ¶ 81. In this regard, when assessing a period of delay caused by a

 3 defendant’s pro se motion to discharge his attorney, our Supreme Court identified the

 4 reasonableness of such a request as the relevant inquiry in determining whether to

 5 assign the resultant delay to the defendant or the state. Id. ¶¶ 53-54. As we explain

 6 below, we think that there is substantial evidence to support the district court’s

 7 finding that Defendant, not his counsel, is responsible for this period of delay.

 8   {53}   In his pro se motion to dismiss his attorney, filed about two weeks before the

 9 April 2012 trial setting, Defendant asserted that his attorney was not communicating

10 with him, not preparing his case for trial, and not providing him with discovery. But

11 against these assertions of fact, Defendant’s attorney said that he had communicated

12 with Defendant, was preparing the case for trial, and had provided Defendant with

13 discovery from the State. Although Mr. Pineda did not submit an affidavit or

14 otherwise testify to his assertions of fact, neither did Defendant. Moreover, Mr.

15 Pineda called his administrative assistant to testify that Defendant had called and told

16 her that he had obtained another attorney who would be suing Mr. Pineda and taking

17 over Defendant’s case. Because Defendant had denied making such an assertion, Mr.

18 Pineda’s assistant’s testimony undermined Defendant’s credibility and provided the

19 district court with a substantial basis for concluding that Defendant’s effort to fire his


                                               26
  1 attorney was a “last-minute plea[] to change counsel [that] should be []viewed

 2 skeptically[,]” not a reasonable invocation of his right to effective trial counsel. Id.

 3 ¶ 53. Accordingly, we assign to Defendant the delay caused by the district court’s

 4 continuance of the April 26, 2012, trial date to July 31, 2012.

 5   {54}   Defendant’s replacement counsel moved to continue the July 31, 2012, trial

 6 date based on the need to conduct additional investigation. Defendant’s attorney

 7 stated that Defendant had been under the mistaken impression that counsel for his co-

 8 Defendant, Mr. Tow, was his attorney, and that this caused several weeks of delay.

 9 Once this misunderstanding had been cleared up, Defendant requested that his

10 attorney conduct additional investigation and track down additional witnesses who

11 Defendant wanted to call to testify in his defense. Although these requests are hardly

12 unreasonable, it does not follow that any delay that resulted must be weighed against

13 the State. The district court did not err in concluding that Defendant should be

14 assigned responsibility for the delay caused by continuing the July 31, 2012, trial

15 setting to October 11, 2012.

16   {55}   We disagree as well with Defendant that the State caused the delay between

17 October 2012 and December 2012. This period of delay was not caused by the district

18 court’s mistaken issuance of a bench warrant for Defendant’s arrest, as defendant

19 argues; rather, it was caused by Defendant’s attorney filing a motion at Defendant’s


                                              27
  1 behest that trial be continued until after April 2014 in order to allow Defendant to

 2 finish an inpatient treatment program at a halfway house. It is worth noting that the

 3 State opposed Defendant’s motion to continue, arguing that granting the motion

 4 would create speedy trial concerns. The State also presented evidence at the hearing

 5 on the motion that tended to refute Defendant’s claim that he was actually enrolled

 6 in an inpatient treatment program. To be sure, confusion over Defendant’s location

 7 might have caused the district court to mistakenly issue a bench warrant and may

 8 have figured into the district court’s decision to delay the trial. But the occasion for

 9 the delay in the first place was Defendant’s request to continue the trial for nearly two

10 years, which the State opposed, and Defendant’s decision to leave the halfway house

11 to seek medical attention, which contributed to the confusion over Defendant’s

12 location. We see no error in the district court’s determination that Defendant should

13 be held responsible for this period of delay.

14   {56}   Although the district court did not enter an order or otherwise explain why it

15 was continuing the December 17, 2012, trial setting, it appears that the reason for the

16 continuance was the State’s December 13, 2012, motion to revoke Defendant’s

17 conditions of release. In that motion, the State stated that it had been told by

18 Defendant’s attorney that “Defendant has failed to maintain contact with defense

19 counsel, and there are no assurances that . . . Defendant will appear for trial on the


                                              28
  1 scheduled trial date.” Defendant later conceded on the morning of trial that he had

 2 failed to stay in contact with his attorney. Although it is not clear whether Defendant

 3 failed to stay in contact with his attorney in order to purposefully delay the December

 4 17, 2012, trial, this evidence provided a sufficient basis for the district court to find

 5 that Defendant “affirmatively cause[d] or acquiesce[d]” in this period of delay.

 6 Serros, 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 74.

 7   {57}   In sum, twelve months of the delay in this case can be assigned to the State;

 8 Defendant caused or acquiesced in the remaining sixteen months’ delay. Since the

 9 majority of the delay in this case was caused by Defendant, we conclude that

10 application of the second Barker factor “tip[s] the balance back in favor of the

11 societal interest in bringing [the d]efendant to trial” and ultimately weighs in favor

12 of the State. Serros, 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 28 (internal quotation marks and citation

13 omitted).

14 3.       Defendant’s Assertion of the Right to a Speedy Trial

15   {58}   The third Barker factor looks to “the frequency and force of the objections[,]

16 as opposed to attaching significant weight to a purely pro forma objection.” Barker,

17 407 U.S. at 529. The right to a speedy trial is

18          fundamental in nature so that a failure to assert [it] does not constitute
19          waiver, but the timeliness and vigor with which the right is asserted may
20          be considered as an indication of whether a defendant was denied


                                               29
  1          needed access to speedy trial over his objection or whether the issue was
 2          raised on appeal as [an] afterthought.

 3 Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶ 32.

 4   {59}   Here, Defendant argues that the two speedy trial demands filed by his

 5 appointed attorneys and his pro se invocations of the right to a speedy trial in his first

 6 motion to dismiss his attorney, his motion for a telephonic setting, and his motion to

 7 dismiss the indictment filed on the eve of trial in April 2013 demonstrate that he

 8 frequently and forcefully asserted his right to a speedy trial.

 9   {60}   In Garza, our Supreme Court held that the defendant’s single speedy trial

10 demand, “preceding his motion to dismiss, tucked within the waiver of arraignment

11 and not guilty plea, was sufficient to assert his right.” Id. ¶ 34. The Court noted that

12 although the defendant’s single invocation of his right to a speedy trial “was not

13 especially vigorous[,]” the fact that the defendant had not otherwise acquiesced in the

14 delay required the third Barker factor to be weighed slightly in his favor. Id.

15   {61}   Here, Defendant invoked his right to a speedy trial five times—twice through

16 his lawyers, and three times through pro se motions to discharge his attorney, set a

17 telephonic hearing, and to dismiss the indictment. Although Defendant invoked his

18 right to a speedy trial many more times than the defendant did in Garza, this fact is

19 mitigated by the context of Defendant’s invocations of the right to a speedy trial: as

20 we have explained above, Defendant’s first two pro se motions to dismiss were filed

                                               30
  1 on the eve of trial and sought a new attorney as the primary relief. Defendant’s pro

 2 se motion to dismiss was likewise filed on the eve of his April 2013 trial, which

 3 ultimately went forward after it was denied. And against Defendant’s invocations of

 4 his right to a speedy trial, Defendant at least once sought to delay his trial by more

 5 than two years in order to avoid violating his conditions of release for an unrelated

 6 criminal conviction.

 7   {62}   Under these circumstances, we cannot say that the district court’s finding that

 8 Defendant did not frequently or forcefully invoke his right to a speedy trial lacks a

 9 substantial basis. See Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶ 32 (quoting Sisneros v. State, 121
10 P.3d 790
, 800 (Wyo. 2005), for the proposition that the third Barker factor should be

11 weighed neutrally where the defendant “demanded a speedy trial throughout the

12 proceedings, but ‘also engaged in procedural maneuvers which had the result of

13 delaying the trial’ ”). Accordingly, we cannot reverse the district court’s ultimate

14 finding to weigh the third Barker factor neutrally.

15 4.       The Prejudice to Defendant Caused by the Delay

16   {63}   The United States Supreme Court in Barker explained the “actual prejudice”

17 prong of the constitutional speedy trial analysis as follows:

18          Prejudice . . . should be assessed in the light of the interests of [the]
19          defendants which the speedy trial right was designed to protect. This
20          Court has identified three such interests: (i) to prevent oppressive
21          pretrial incarceration; (ii) to minimize anxiety and concern of the

                                               31
  1          accused; and (iii) to limit the possibility that the defense will be
 2          impaired.

 3 407 U.S. at 532; see State v. Maddox, 2008-NMSC-062, ¶ 32,
145 N.M. 242
, 195
4 P.3d 1254
, abrogated on other grounds by Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶¶ 47-48.

 5   {64}   “Ordinarily, a defendant bears the burden of proof on this factor by showing

 6 ‘particularized prejudice’ when claiming a speedy trial violation.” Serros, 2016-

 7 NMSC-008, ¶ 86 (quoting Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶ 39). “However, if the length

 8 of delay and the reasons for the delay weigh heavily in [the] defendant’s favor and

 9 [the] defendant has asserted his right and not acquiesced to the delay, then the

10 defendant need not show prejudice for a court to conclude that the defendant’s right

11 has been violated.” Serros, 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 86 (internal quotation marks and

12 citation omitted).

13   {65}   At the hearing on Defendant’s final motion to dismiss on speedy trial grounds,

14 the district court explained why it concluded Defendant had failed to demonstrate

15 particularized prejudice. The court stated:

16          [W]ithout going through all the dates of when he was arrested, where he
17          was arrested and why he was arrested, [I am] unable to state whether he
18          served any—much, if any, pretrial incarceration time on this case. I
19          know he was brought here from Luna County, so he’s currently in
20          custody in Luna County. So I don’t think there is going to be [any]
21          impressive pretrial incarceration. With regard to it having any impact on
22          his ability to mount a defense, I’ve heard nothing about that today.




                                               32
  1   {66}   Defendant first argues that the district court erred by assigning the burden of

 2 proving prejudice instead of requiring the State to prove the absence of prejudice. But

 3 Salandre v. State, 1991-NMSC-016,
111 N.M. 422
,
806 P.2d 562
, the case that

 4 Defendant cites in support of this proposition, was modified by Garza, which

 5 expressly held that Salandre should not be read to impose on the State a burden of

 6 disproving prejudice. See Garza, 2009-NMSC-038, ¶¶ 15-24 (“In light of the

 7 overwhelming consensus among the federal Circuit Courts of Appeals and our policy

 8 of providing a functional analysis based on the facts and circumstances of each case,

 9 we abolish [Salandre’s] presumption that a defendant’s right to a speedy trial has

10 been violated based solely on the threshold determination that the length of delay is

11 ‘presumptively prejudicial.’ ”). Under Garza, Defendant bears the burden to identify

12 and sufficiently establish particularized prejudice stemming from the presumptively

13 prejudicial delays in this case.

14   {67}   In this regard, Defendant argues that his pro se motions to dismiss his attorney

15 and dismiss the indictment on speedy trial grounds “express[] overwhelming concern

16 over the status of his case[.]” Defendant also points out that he was incarcerated for

17 a significant portion of the delays at issue. These facts, Defendant claims, refute the

18 district court’s conclusion that Defendant did not suffer particularized prejudice as

19 a result of the presumptively prejudicial delays in this case.


                                               33
  1   {68}   The problem with this argument is that it depends on two factual inferences

 2 that the district court was free to ignore given evidence tending to refute Defendant’s

 3 claim that he had long been asserting his speedy trial rights and had not caused the

 4 delays at issue. The first inference is that Defendant’s expressions of “overwhelming

 5 concern over the status of his case” in his pro se motions were sincere. See Serros,

 6 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 88 (finding particularized prejudice prejudice based on lengthy

 7 pretrial incarceration based on the defendant’s “unchallenged testimony at the hearing

 8 on his motion to dismiss, in which he described his living conditions for the previous

 9 four years”). Here, Defendant’s attorney provided evidence that Defendant was

10 seeking to fire him not because of a lack of communication but because he was

11 unhappy with the State’s plea offer, and Defendant had deliberately sought to

12 sabotage the attorney-client relationship by seeking out another attorney and

13 threatening to sue him. Given this evidence, the district court could permissibly view

14 Defendant’s speedy trial complaints as part of an effort to derail the case on the eve

15 of trial, not a genuine desire for finality.

16   {69}   The second inference is that Defendant’s pretrial incarceration was caused by

17 the delays in this case. As Defendant concedes, he was released on bond roughly six

18 months after his arrest. While this period of incarceration can certainly be considered

19 prejudicial in the present case, it cannot simply be lumped together with the periods


                                                  34
  1 of incarceration that resulted from Defendant’s parole violations in unrelated cases,

 2 as the district court noted in its oral findings on prejudice. Properly assigned, it is

 3 clear that Defendant was incarcerated based upon the instant charges for at most six

 4 months of the total period of delay at issue in this case. We do not think that the

 5 prejudice Defendant suffered as a result of his incarceration after his arrest in the

 6 present case is enough to find that Defendant was prejudiced by the entire twenty-

 7 nine month delay in this case. Cf. Id., 2016-NMSC-008, ¶ 93 (upholding a district

 8 court’s finding of prejudice arising from the defendant’s incarceration in

 9 administrative segregation for the entire period of pretrial delay). Indeed, the record

10 indicates Defendant was in and out of jail following his initial satisfaction of bail in

11 this case based upon his own actions before and after the relevant arrest and release

12 from incarceration in the present case.

13   {70}   Defendant finally argues that because of the delays in bringing his case to trial,

14 he suffered particularized prejudice because he lost the opportunity to serve his

15 sentence in this case concurrently with his sentences for unrelated criminal

16 convictions. See State v. Zurla, 1990-NMSC-011, ¶ 23,
109 N.M. 640
,
789 P.2d 588

17 (“[The appellate courts] believe loss of the possibility of serving concurrent sentences

18 did constitute an aspect of prejudice.”). But Zurla, which Defendant cites in support

19 of his argument, weighed the second Barker factor heavily against the state, finding


                                                35
  1 that its negligence was the cause of all of the delays at issue. Zurla, 1990-NMSC-011,

 2 ¶¶ 14-17. Here, as we have already explained, a significant amount of the delay in this

 3 case was caused by Defendant. Without explaining how the delays caused by the

 4 State (rather than those caused by Defendant) resulted in Defendant’s lost opportunity

 5 to serve concurrent sentences, we do not think Defendant has demonstrated

 6 particularized prejudice on this ground.

 7   {71}   For the foregoing reasons, we conclude that the district court correctly found

 8 that Defendant had failed to demonstrate particularized prejudice arising from the

 9 delays in this case.

10 5.       Balancing the Factors

11   {72}   To recapitulate, the first Barker factor strongly favors Defendant; the nearly

12 twenty-nine month long delay in this case exceeds the amount of time that a criminal

13 case of intermediate complexity is presumed to require. See Serros, 2016-NMSC-008,

14 ¶ 23. However, this is the only Barker factor that ultimately weighs in Defendant’s

15 favor. As for the second Barker factor, Defendant expressed his desire to bring his

16 case to trial but inconsistently interposed numerous delays and requested

17 continuances of scheduled trial dates, all reasons for delay that weigh in the State’s

18 favor. We attach particular importance to Defendant’s repeated efforts to delay trial

19 by more than two years in order to prioritize fulfilling his conditions of probation in


                                              36
  1 an unrelated case. Ultimately, the district court accurately weighed this second Barker

 2 factor in favor of the State. Defendant’s inconsistent assertions of his speedy trial

 3 right while simultaneously requesting continuances of trial settings also supported the

 4 district court’s determination regarding the third Barker factor, a reasonably vigorous

 5 assertion of one’s right to a speedy trial. We conclude that assigning neutrality to this

 6 third Barker factor was not error under the facts presented in this case. Finally,

 7 Defendant failed to identify or establish particularized prejudice under the fourth

 8 Barker factor. As a result, our de novo review of all four speedy trial factors support

 9 the district court’s conclusion that Defendant’s speedy trial rights were not violated.

10 III.     CONCLUSION

11   {73}   We affirm the district court’s denial of Defendant’s motion to dismiss on

12 speedy trial grounds. We also reject Defendant’s challenge to the sufficiency of the

13 evidence supporting his conviction for conspiracy to commit forgery.

14   {74}   Defendant’s conviction is affirmed.

15   {75}   IT IS SO ORDERED.
